bitfield.description: Module ID field
RTL revision. Will vary depending on release.
Major revision.
Minor revision. CPPI DMA Revision Register
This field controls which of the 4 Queue Managers the DMA will access in order to allocate a channel teardown descriptor from the teardown descriptor queue.
This field controls which of the 2K queues in the indicated queue manager should be read in order to allocate channel teardown descriptors. CPPI DMA Teardown Free Descriptor Queue Control Register
Control for emulation pause request 1 = Does not force emu_pause_req low 0 = Forces emu_pause_req low
Enable for emulation suspend CPPI DMA Emulation Control Register
This field enables or disables the channel 0 = channel is disabled 1 = channel is enabled This field will be cleared after a channel teardown is complete.
Setting this bit will request the channel to be torn down. This field will remain set after a channel teardown is complete.
This field controls the default queue manager number that will be used to queue teardown descriptors back to the host.
This field controls the default queue number within the selected queue manager onto which teardown descriptors will be queued back to the host. Table 98 -Tx Channel N Global Configuration Registers
This field enables or disables the channel 0 = channel is disabled 1 = channel is enabled This field will be cleared after a channel teardown is complete.
This field indicates whether or not an Rx teardown operation is complete. This field should be cleared when a channel is initialized. This field will be set after a channel teardown is complete.
Setting this bit causes the CPPI DMA to be suspended for rx channels. If a pause is being requested and the channel is not in a packet then drop the credit.

This bit controls the error handling mode for the channel and is only used when channel errors (i.e. descriptor or buffer starvation occurs): 0 = Starvation errors result in dropping packet and reclaiming any used descriptor or buffer resources back to the original queues/pools they were allocated to 1 = Starvation errors result in subsequent re-try of the descriptor allocation operation. In this mode, the DMA will return to the IDLE state without saving it's internal operational state back to the internal state RAM and without issuing an advance operation on the FIFO interface. This results in the DMA re-initiating the FIFO block transfer at a later time with the intention that additional free buffers and/or descriptors will have been added. Regardless of the value of this bit, the DMA will assert the cdma_rx_sof_overrun (for SOP) or cdma_rx_mof_overrun (for non-SOP) when

This field specifies the number of bytes that are to be skipped in the SOP buffer before beginning to write the payload. This value must be less than the minimum size of a buffer in the system. Valid values are 0 - 255 bytes.

This field indicates the default descriptor type to use: 0 = Reserved 1 = Host 2 = Reserved 3 = Reserved The actual descriptor type that will be used for reception can be overridden by information provided in the CPPI FIFO data block.
This field indicates the default receive queue manager that this channel should use. The actual receive queue manager index can be overridden by information provided in the CPPI FIFO data block.

This field indicates the default receive queue that this channel should use. The actual receive queue that will be used for reception can be overridden by information provided in the CPPI FIFO data block. Table 99 -Rx Channel N Global Configuration Registers
This field specifies which Buffer Manager should be used for the second Rx buffer in a host type packet.
This field specifies which Free Descriptor / Buffer Pool should be used for the 2nd Rx buffer in a host type packet
This field specifies which Buffer Manager should be used for the second Rx buffer in a host type packet.
This field specifies which Free Descriptor / Buffer Pool should be used for the 1st Rx buffer in a host type packet Table 100 -Rx Channel N Host Packet Configuration Registers A
This field specifies which Manager should be used for the 4th or later Rx buffers in a host type packet
This field specifies which Free Descriptor Queue should be used for the 4th or later Rx buffers in a host type packet
This field specifies which Buffer Manager should be used for the 3rd Rx buffer in a host type packet
This field specifies which Free Descriptor / Buffer Pool should be used for the 3rd Rx buffer in a host type packet Table 101 -Rx Channel N Host Packet Configuration Registers B

This results in the DMA re-initiating the FIFO block transfer at a later time with the intention that additional free buffers and/or descriptors will have been added. Regardless of the value of this bit, the DMA will assert the cdma_rx_sof_overrun (for SOP) or cdma_rx_mof_overrun (for non-SOP) when

This field specifies the number of bytes that are to be skipped in the SOP buffer before beginning to write the payload. This value must be less than the minimum size of a buffer in the system. Valid values are 0 - 255 bytes.

This field enables or disables the channel 0 = channel is disabled 1 = channel is enabled This field will be cleared after a channel teardown is complete.
This field indicates whether or not an Rx teardown operation is complete. This field should be cleared when a channel is initialized. This field will be set after a channel teardown is complete.
Setting this bit causes the CPPI DMA to be suspended for rx channels. If a pause is being requested and the channel is not in a packet then drop the credit.

This bit controls the error handling mode for the channel and is only used when channel errors (i.e. descriptor or buffer starvation occurs): 0 = Starvation errors result in dropping packet and reclaiming any used descriptor or buffer resources back to the original queues/pools they were allocated to 1 = Starvation errors result in subsequent re-try of the descriptor allocation operation. In this mode, the DMA will return to the IDLE state without saving it's internal operational state back to the internal state RAM and without issuing an advance operation on the FIFO interface. This results in the DMA re-initiating the FIFO block transfer at a later time with the intention that additional free buffers and/or descriptors will have been added. Regardless of the value of this bit, the DMA will assert the cdma_rx_sof_overrun (for SOP) or cdma_rx_mof_overrun (for non-SOP) when

This field specifies the number of bytes that are to be skipped in the SOP buffer before beginning to write the payload. This value must be less than the minimum size of a buffer in the system. Valid values are 0 - 255 bytes.

In this mode, the DMA will return to the IDLE state without saving it's internal operational state back to the internal state RAM and without issuing an advance operation on the FIFO interface. This results in the DMA re-initiating the FIFO block transfer at a later time with the intention that additional free buffers and/or descriptors will have been added. Regardless of the value of this bit, the DMA will assert the cdma_rx_sof_overrun (for SOP) or cdma_rx_mof_overrun (for non-SOP) when

This field specifies the number of bytes that are to be skipped in the SOP buffer before beginning to write the payload. This value must be less than the minimum size of a buffer in the system. Valid values are 0 - 255 bytes.

This field indicates the default descriptor type to use: 0 = Reserved 1 = Host 2 = Reserved 3 = Reserved The actual descriptor type that will be used for reception can be overridden by information provided in the CPPI FIFO data block.
This field indicates the default receive queue manager that this channel should use. The actual receive queue manager index can be overridden by information provided in the CPPI FIFO data block.

This field indicates the default receive queue that this channel should use. The actual receive queue that will be used for reception can be overridden by information provided in the CPPI FIFO data block. Table 99 -Rx Channel N Global Configuration Registers

This field enables or disables the channel 0 = channel is disabled 1 = channel is enabled This field will be cleared after a channel teardown is complete.
Setting this bit will request the channel to be torn down. This field will remain set after a channel teardown is complete.
This field controls the default queue manager number that will be used to queue teardown descriptors back to the host.
This field controls the default queue number within the selected queue manager onto which teardown descriptors will be queued back to the host. Table 98 -Tx Channel N Global Configuration Registers
This field enables or disables the channel 0 = channel is disabled 1 = channel is enabled This field will be cleared after a channel teardown is complete.
This field indicates whether or not an Rx teardown operation is complete. This field should be cleared when a channel is initialized. This field will be set after a channel teardown is complete.
